quizzes.title: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf
quizzes.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: What is XML?
questions.explanation: XML stands for eXtensible Markup Language.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: Which of the following best describes the role of XML as a metalanguage?

options.text: A language for executing complex machine instructions.
A language used to describe other languages, enabling customized tags and functionality.
A language for rendering graphics in web browsers.
A language used to manage databases.

questions.explanation: XML is a metalanguage, meaning it's 'a language for describing other languages' that allows designers to create custom tags and provide functionality not available with HTML.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: A metalanguage (a language for describing other languages) that enables designers to create their own customized tags to provide functionality not available with HTML

questions.prompt: What is SGML?

options.text: A standard for creating web pages.
A system for defining structured document types and markup languages to represent instances of those document types

questions.explanation: SGML (Standard Generalized Markup Language) is a system for defining structured document types and markup languages to represent instances of those document types.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Is a system for defining structured document types and markup languages to represent instances of those document types

questions.prompt: Which of the following is an advantage of XML?
questions.explanation: XML has several advantages, including simplicity (tex-based, human-legible).

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: What are the key components of an XML document?
questions.explanation: XML documents contain key components such as the root element, other elements, and attributes.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: In XML, how are elements defined?

options.text: Elements begin with an end-tag and end with a start-tag.
Elements or tags are the least common form of markup.
Elements begin with a start-tag and end with an end-tag.

questions.explanation: In XML, elements begin with a start-tag and end with an end-tag. XML elements are also case-sensitive.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Elements or tags are most common form of markup.
Element begin with start-tag and end with end-tag.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of attributes in XML?

options.text: To define the structure of the XML document.
To provide descriptive information about an element.
To create new elements in the XML document.
To define comments in the XML document.

questions.explanation: Attributes in XML are name-value pairs that contain descriptive information about an element.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Attributes are name-value pairs that contain descriptive information about an element

questions.prompt: What is the proper way to embed an attribute in XML?
questions.explanation: The proper way to embed an attribute in XML is to do so within the start tag.  The attribute value is enclosed in quotes.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Attribute is placed inside start-tag after corresponding element name with the attribute value enclosed in quotes.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of comments in XML?

options.text: To define the structure of the document.
To provide documentation and notes within the XML file that are ignored by the parser.
To execute functions within the XML document.
To define variables in the XML document.

questions.explanation: Comments in XML are used to provide documentation and notes within the XML file. They are ignored by the XML parser.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of entity references in XML?

options.text: To define the structure of the document.
To serve as shortcuts to often-repeated text or to include the content of external files.
To define functions within the XML document.
To define variables in the XML document.

questions.explanation: Entity references serve three main purposes, including acting as shortcuts to often-repeated text or including the content of external files.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: as shortcut to often-repeated text or include the content of external files

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of a CDATA section in XML?

options.text: To define a new element in XML.
To instruct the XML processor to ignore markup characters and pass the enclosed text directly to the application without interpretation.
To declare a constant value in XML.

questions.explanation: A CDATA section in XML instructs the XML processor to ignore markup characters and pass the enclosed text directly to the application without interpretation.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: A CDATA section instructs the XML processor to ignore markup characters and pass the enclosed text directly to the application without interpretation.

questions.prompt: In XML, are elements ordered or unordered?
questions.explanation: In XML, elements are ordered, meaning the sequence in which they appear matters.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: What best describes semi-structured data?

options.text: Data that has some structure, but may not be regular or complete.

questions.explanation: Semi-structured data is 'Data that has some structure, but may not be regular or complete'.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Data that has some structure, but may not be regular or complete

questions.prompt: What does it mean for semi-structured data to be 'schema-less'?

options.text: It conforms to a fixed schema.
It does not conform to a fixed schema.
It is only for relational databases.
The schema is separate from the data.

questions.explanation: Schema-less means semi-structured data does 'not conform to a fixed schema'.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Does not conform to a fixed schema (schema-less or self-describing)

questions.prompt: Where is the schema information contained in semi-structured data?
questions.explanation: The schema information for semi-structured data is contained within the data itself.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Information about a schema is contained within the data itself

questions.prompt: Which of the following are advantages of using XML? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Advantages of XML include simplicity, open standard and platform/vendor-independence, and extensibility.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what are the two components that SGML allows a document to be logically separated into?

options.text: The structure of the document (Document Type Definition) and Text

questions.explanation: SGML allows a document to be logically separated into two parts: the structure of the document called Document Type Definition (DTD) and Text.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: SGML allows a document to be logically separated into two:
The structure of the document called Document Type Definition (DTD)

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what does the XML declaration specify?

options.text: The styling rules for the document
The default behavior of the browser
The XML version, encoding, and standalone status.

questions.explanation: XML declaration specifies the XML version, character encoding, and whether the document is standalone.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

questions.prompt: In the context of XML, what is the purpose of the root element?

options.text: To define attributes for other elements
To serve as the top-level element that contains all other elements
To specify the stylesheet for the document

questions.explanation: The root element in XML is the top-level element that contains all other elements in the document.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: First element must be a root element, which can contain other (sub)elements.

questions.prompt: According to the slides, what are the key benefits of XML? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Support for the integration of data from multiple sources

questions.explanation: XML offers several advantages, including improved load balancing, support for integrating data from multiple sources, and extensibility, making it versatile for diverse applications.

source.pdfName: INT305_Week01 Introduction to XML and DTD.pdf

snippets: Improved load balancing (delivered to the browser for local computation)
Support for the integration of data from multiple sources
